edu.bu.hw3.linalg

Class Matrix

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.bu.hw3.linalg.Matrix

  • public class Matrix
extends java.lang.Object
    The Matrix class which stores elements in a dense format. A Matrix currently is only allowed to be 2d (meaning row/col vectors and singletons supported) This class stores all entries as double values, which is markedly different than most other linear algebra packages which support multiple datatypes. This class is not optimized like other packages are, so operations (like transpose) induce a deep-copy of the underlying data, which is strictly not necessary. This class does not support masking, a limitation induced by only supporting double values.

      • toStringData

        public java.lang.String toStringData()
        A method to write the Matrix in a (non-human-readable) String representation. This representation is used when saving the Matrix to a file, and is much easier to parse than the human-readable String rep.
        Returns:
        The non-human-readable but much easier to parse String representation of this Matrix.

      • loadStringData

        public void loadStringData(java.lang.String data)
                    throws java.lang.Exception
        A method to parse a non-human-readable (i.e. the output of Matrix.toStringData()) Matrix String representation and overwrite the current entries with the parsed entries. The Shape information contained within the String and the Shape of this matrix must match (i.e. same dimensionality) otherwise an Exception is thrown.
        Parameters:
        data - The non-human-readable (i.e. the output of Matrix.toStringData()) String representation of a Matrix
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • sum

        public Matrix sum(int dim)
           throws java.lang.Exception
        A method to get the sum along an dim of this Matrix. The specified dim will be collapsed down to 1. For instance, Matrix.sum(0) sums along the rows of the Matrix, producing a row vector, while Matrix.sum(1) will sum along the cols of the Matrix, producing a column vector.
        Parameters:
        dim - The dimension to sum along
        Returns:
        The sum of this Matrix along the specified dim
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • matmul

        public Matrix matmul(Matrix other)
              throws java.lang.Exception
        A method to Matrix multiply this Matrix with another in the followign order: this * other
        Parameters:
        other - The other matrix to matmul this Matrix with
        Returns:
        The result of the matmul
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • add

        public Matrix add(Matrix other)
           throws java.lang.Exception
        A method to add this Matrix with another Matrix, supporting broadcasting. Broadcasting is when we infer the operation based on the dimensions of the arguments. For instance, adding a (2,2) with a (1,2) implies that we should add the (1,2) to each row of the (2,2) rather than requring the user to first repeat the (1,2) manually (and wasting lots of space).
        Parameters:
        other - The other matrix to add to this one
        Returns:
        The result of addition
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • subtract

        public Matrix subtract(Matrix other)
                throws java.lang.Exception
        A method to subtract this Matrix with another Matrix, supporting broadcasting. Broadcasting is when we infer the operation based on the dimensions of the arguments. For instance, subtracting a (2,2) with a (1,2) implies that we should subtract the (1,2) from each row of the (2,2) rather than requring the user to first repeat the (1,2) manually (and wasting lots of space).
        Parameters:
        other - The other matrix to add to this one
        Returns:
        The result of subtraction
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • emul

        public Matrix emul(Matrix other)
            throws java.lang.Exception
        A method to element-wise multiply this Matrix with another Matrix, supporting broadcasting. Broadcasting is when we infer the operation based on the dimensions of the arguments. For instance, emul a (2,2) with a (1,2) implies that we should element-wise multiply the (1,2) with each row of the (2,2) rather than requring the user to first repeat the (1,2) manually (and wasting lots of space).
        Parameters:
        other - The other matrix to add to this one
        Returns:
        The result of element-wise multiplication
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • ediv

        public Matrix ediv(Matrix other)
            throws java.lang.Exception
        A method to element-wise divide this Matrix with another Matrix, supporting broadcasting. Broadcasting is when we infer the operation based on the dimensions of the arguments. For instance, ediv a (2,2) with a (1,2) implies that we should element-wise divide the (1,2) with each row of the (2,2) rather than requring the user to first repeat the (1,2) manually (and wasting lots of space).
        Parameters:
        other - The other matrix to add to this one
        Returns:
        The result of element-wise divide
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • reshape

        public Matrix reshape(int numRows,
                      int numCols)
               throws java.lang.Exception
        A method to view the same entries but according to another shape. This method produces a brand new copy of the entries, which is wasteful but easier to implement. If you choose, one dimension can be set to -1 in which case the method will figure out the value for that dimension. The specified dimensions must contain the same number of elements as this Matrix does.
        Parameters:
        numRows - the specified new number of rows
        numCols - the specified new number of cols
        Returns:
        the reshaped Matrix with a fresh copy of the data (wasteful)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • norm

        public Matrix norm(int p)
        A method to calculate the p norm of this Matrix, as if we unrolled this Matrix into one large vector and then applied the norm to this vector. This is a vector norm, not a Matrix norm
        Parameters:
        p - The type of norm to apply (2 for euclidean, 1 for manhattan, etc.)
        Returns:
        Singleton Matrix containing the p-norm of this Matrix if it was unrolled into a large vector first

      • diag

      • max

        public static Matrix max(Matrix a,
                         Matrix b)
                  throws java.lang.Exception
        A static method to get a Matrix whose entries are computed element-wise between the two arguments (i.e. output(r, c) = max(a(r,c), b(r,c)) The two arguments must have the same shape
        Parameters:
        a - The first Matrix
        b - The other Matrix
        Returns:
        the Matrix
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • max

        public static Matrix max(Matrix a,
                         double val)
        A static method to get a Matrix whose entries are computed element-wise between the the first arg and the second (i.e. output(r, c) = max(a(r,c), val)
        Parameters:
        a - The first Matrix
        val - The value to compare against
        Returns:
        the Matrix

      • clip

        public static Matrix clip(Matrix X,
                          double lower,
                          double upper)
                   throws java.lang.Exception
        A static method to clip each entry of Matrix X to be between the lower and upper values
        Parameters:
        X - the Matrix whose entries should be clipped
        lower - the lowest value allowed. All entries lower than this will be set to this value
        upper - the highest value allowed. All entries higher than this will be set to this value
        Returns:
        the clipped Matrix
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
